org_name: Community Health Center of Central Missouri

request_pathways.name: Authorization for Use and Disclosure of Protected Health Information (2025)
Mail to PO Box 104780, Jefferson City, MO
Email submission (listed on form, no address specified)
Hold for pickup at clinic location

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic ROI authorization PDF, prints and handwrites entries, then submits via fax, mail, email, or in-person pickup.

red_flags: Witness signature required — not mandated by HIPAA and creates a barrier for patients submitting from home
Sensitive records bundled into all-or-nothing authorization (mental health, substance abuse, HIV/AIDS, genetic testing) without granular opt-in/opt-out — may conflict with 42 CFR Part 2
bright_spots: Email listed as a delivery option alongside fax and mail — uncommon among ROI forms
Preset date range options (Last 12 months, Last 24 months) reduce friction for common requests
Comprehensive record type selection with 10 named categories plus Other

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — a basic web search immediately returned direct PDF download links with no navigation, bot blocking, or login walls required.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds; fax submission available — the PDF has a text layer but zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite, though patients can submit via fax or email.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but has notable problems — the one-page form has logical flow but the FROM/TO structure confuses self-access patients, the acknowledgment is dense legalese in one paragraph, and the form contains typos and ZIP code inconsistencies.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization form treats all disclosures identically with no dedicated patient access pathway, no Right of Access language, and a FROM/TO structure designed for provider-to-provider transfers.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — the witness signature is not HIPAA-mandated, sensitive records are bundled without granular consent (potential 42 CFR Part 2 issue), and fees are not disclosed.

overall.summary: CHCCMO earns high marks for easy findability but is held back by a generic authorization form with no fillable fields, no patient access differentiation, a witness requirement, and dense legal language — resulting in a middling patient experience.
